description:
Api for creating and managing Groups and their members.

The Group endpoints manage groups required for other systems.  These groups can go on to have permissions assigned to them.

The Members endpoints manage members of the groups previously created.  Members can only be added or removed from a group, they can not be updated.
title: AAA Groups API

methods.description:
Example Url Calls:
  • Get with specified limit:
    • /api/groups?limit=10
  • Get without limit:
    • /api/groups
  • Get with memberId of 8c1e6a94-651c-4b99-9186-cf4f58e6e6e8 and memberType of users:
    • /api/groups?memberId=8c1e6a94-651c-4b99-9186-cf4f58e6e6e8&memberType=users
  • Get with memberId of 8c1e6a94-651c-4b99-9186-cf4f58e6e6e8 and memberType of users and limit of 10:
    • /api/groups?memberId=8c1e6a94-651c-4b99-9186-cf4f58e6e6e8&memberType=users&limit=10
  • Get groups modified since 11:00 UTC on April 30, 2021:
    • /api/groups?updatedOn=2021-04-30T11:00:00Z
  • Get groups created by user 686c40b9-f4e1-4bc2-aa96-39007da0ed81:
      /api/groups?createdBy=686c40b9-f4e1-4bc2-aa96-39007da0ed81
  • Get with specified offset:
    • /api/groups?offset=10

Implementation Notes:
  • The new Group object in the body of the request will have all fields validated before creating the record.

Implementation Notes:
  • The id of the Group to be deleted is checked for existence before executing the delete process.

Implementation Notes:
  • A record will only be returned if the calling user has permission to view the group.

Implementation Notes:
  • The Group object in the body of the request will have all fields validated before attempting an update.
  • The version number in the Group object must match the version number of the record in our data store.

Implementation Notes:
  • The id of the Group the members belong to is checked for existence before executing the member delete process.

Example Url Calls:
  • Get with specified limit:
    • /api/groups/{id}/members?limit=10
  • Get without limit:
    • /api/groups/{id}/members
  • Get with specified offset:
    • /api/groups/{id}/members?offset=10

Implementation Notes:
  • The new Group object in the body of the request will have all fields validated before creating the record.

description: Retrieve Intraday and Interday time series historical pricing data. The returned response will be in json tabular format.
title: Time Series Historical Pricing Web Service

methods.description: To retrieve a multiple records of time series pricing events (i.e. trades, quotes and corrections) data. The default timeout is 3 minutes.

endpoints.summary: A latest historical pricing event data

methods.description: To retrieve time series pricing events (i.e. trades, quotes and corrections) data. The default timeout is 3 minutes.

The interface returns a single Interday summary record (the latest record not beyond the specified end date) for each instrument in the universe list.
The data lookback logic is considered for each instrument separately, meaning that, at least one field of the returned record is guaranteed to have a non-null value but the date of response data may not be the same.
No data will be returned when all of the requested fields have no value within the lookback period. The lookback period is dependent on the native interval of each instrument.
* Daily : 30 days
* Weekly : 14 days
* Monthly : 62 days
* Quarterly : 183 days
* Yearly : 732 days

endpoints.summary: A single Interday summary record for each instrument in the universe list

description: Technical Product Master API
title: Technical Product Master API

methods.description:
Returns Products. When `productIds` and/or `onDemandProducts` is set, a response is limited to requested Product Ids and/or "On Demand" products respectively. `ProductIds` can contain up to __100__ items.

When neither `productIds` or `onDemandProducts` is set, a response then represents a pageable operation, enabling the caller to traverse across existing Products, page by page.

A pageable operation can be controlled using `limit` and `pagination` parameters, where `limit` indicates the number of desired items per page, and `pagination` represents a pagination token referring to a particular page, which can be obtained from either `next` or `previous` fields within a prior pageable response. When `pagination` is omitted, a response always represents the very first page. Maximum supported `limit` is __1000__.

Evaluates a collection of Products against User Portfolio to determine whether assignment can be completed, and provides the requirements (if any) to complete the assignment.

In a `entity` object, all fields (`uuid`, `type` and `properties.country`) are mandatory.

`userPortfolio` object represents a portfolio of the User. It contains a `productList` collection of objects (`productId` to `deploymentMethod` pairs). Portfolio itself can be empty.

`assignments` array can contain assignments, where `product` object contains `productId` to `deploymentMethod` pair of values, and `assignmentAction` should be either '__add__' or '__delete__'

`type` should be either '__human__' or '__serviceaccount__'

Returns technical products. The search is carried out by the search parameter `technicalProduct` and `unlinkedOnly`. When `technicalProduct` is set and `unlinkedOnly` is false, a response returns all technical products linked to commercial products that Id or Name contains `technicalProduct`. When `unlinkedOnly` is true, filtering will be based on unlinked technical products. A response is limited to requested technical products.

When `technicalProduct` is not set, a response returns all technical products linked (`unlinkedOnly` is false) or unlinked (`unlinkedOnly` is true) to commercial products.

A pageable operation can be controlled using `limit` and `offset` parameters, where `limit` indicates the number of desired items per page, and `offset` specifies how many technical products to skip in the response. Maximum supported `limit` is __100__.

description: LUSID Portfolios API
title: LUSID API for Refinitiv Data Platform

methods.description:
Get the set of cash flows that occur in a window for the transaction portfolio's instruments.
            
Note that grouping can affect the quantity of information returned; where a holding is an amalgamation of one or more (e.g. cash) instruments, a unique
transaction identifier will not be available. The same may go for diagnostic information (e.g. multiple sources of an aggregate cash amount on a date that is
not split out. Grouping at the transaction and instrument level is recommended for those seeking to attribute individual flows.

Cancel all previous holding adjustments made on the specified transaction portfolio for a specified effective
datetime. This should be used to undo holding adjustments made via set holdings or adjust holdings.
Get the holdings of the specified transaction portfolio.

Set the holdings of the specified transaction portfolio to the provided targets. LUSID will automatically
construct adjustment transactions to ensure that the entire set of holdings for the transaction portfolio
are always set to the provided targets for the specified effective datetime. Read more about the difference between
adjusting and setting holdings here https://support.lusid.com/how-do-i-adjust-my-holdings.

endpoints.summary: Get/Set/Adjust/Delete holdings for a transaction portfolio

methods.description: Calculate holdings for a transaction portfolio.

endpoints.summary: Get holdings for a date range

methods.description: Add a single portfolio to a portfolio group.
List all the portfolio summaries matching particular criteria.

Delete a single portfolio. The deletion of the portfolio will be valid from the portfolio's creation datetime. This means that the portfolio will no longer exist at any effective datetime from the asAt datetime of deletion.
Retrieve the definition of a single portfolio.

Update the definition of a single portfolio. Not all elements within a portfolio definition are
modifiable due to the potential implications for data already stored against the portfolio.
List the holdings adjustments made to the specified transaction portfolio over a specified interval of effective time.
Remove a single portfolio group (sub group) from a portfolio group.

We bucket/aggregate a transaction portfolio's instruments by date or tenor specified in the request.
The cashflows are grouped by both instrumentId and currency. 
            
If you want transactional level cashflow, please use the 'GetUpsertableCashFlows' endpoint.
If you want instrument cashflow, please use the 'GetPortfolioCashFlows' endpoint.
Note that these endpoints do not apply bucketing.

endpoints.summary: Get bucketed cash flows from a list of portfolios

methods.description: List all the portfolio groups in a single scope.

Get a cash ladder for a transaction portfolio.
List all the portfolios matching the specified criteria.

Delete one or more properties from a single portfolio. If the properties are time variant then an effective date time from which the properties
will be deleted must be specified. If the properties are perpetual then it is invalid to specify an effective date time for deletion.
List all the properties of a single portfolio.

Update or insert one or more properties onto a single portfolio. A property will be updated if it
already exists and inserted if it does not. All properties must be of the domain 'Portfolio'.
List all the properties of a single portfolio.

Get the set of cash flows that occur in a window for the given portfolio instruments as a set of upsertable transactions (DTOs).
            
Note that grouping can affect the quantity of information returned; where a holding is an amalgamation of one or more (e.g. cash) instruments, a unique
transaction identifier will not be available. The same may go for diagnostic information (e.g. multiple sources of an aggregate cash amount on a date that is
not split out. Grouping at the transaction and instrument level is recommended for those seeking to attribute individual flows.
            
In essence this is identical to the 'GetCashFlows' endpoint but returns the cash flows as a set of transactions suitable for directly putting back into LUSID.
There are a couple of important points:
(1) Internally it can not be fully known where the user wishes to insert these transactions, e.g. portfolio and movement type.
    These are therefore defaulted to a sensible option; the user will likely need to change these.
(2) Similarly, knowledge of any properties the user might wish to add to a transaction are unknown and consequently left empty.
(3) The transaction id that is added is simply a concatenation of the original transaction id, instrument id and payment date and direction. The user can happily override this.
Create a transaction portfolio in a specific scope.
Get an A2B report for the given portfolio.
Get a cash statement for a transaction portfolio.

Builds and returns all transactions that affect the holdings of a portfolio over a given interval of
effective time into a set of output transactions. This includes transactions automatically generated by
LUSID such as holding adjustments.

methods.description:

will be deleted must be specified. If the properties are perpetual then it is invalid to specify an effective date time for deletion.

union set of all transactions of the parent (and any grandparents etc.) and the specified derived transaction portfolio itself.

union set of all transactions of the parent (and any grandparents etc.) and the specified derived transaction portfolio itself.

methods.description:
Upsert a trade ticket. This is broadly equivalent to a singular call to upsert an instrument, then a counterparty and finally
a transaction that makes use of the two. It can be viewed as a utility function or part of a workflow more familiar to users
with OTC systems than flow and equity trading ones.

    • or
    • /api/identities-details?searchCriteria=8b7dbbb0-a43f-4c6c-a339-cf11b8b04f72
  • Searching by Name:
    • /api/identities-details?searchCriteria=clientname&searchType=name
  • Searching by CertificateHash:
    • /api/identities-details?searchCriteria=hash&searchType=certificatehash
  • Searching with pagination:
    • /api/identities-details?limit=50&offset=0

Implementation Notes:
  • The id of the AppIdentity to be mapped is checked for existence before calling the map process.
  • If mapping target is AppAccount; the AppAccount is checked for existence before calling the map process.
  • If mapping target is AopServiceAccount; the ServiceAccount is checked for existence before calling the map process.

methods.description: List all the instruments that have been mastered in the LUSID instrument master.

Update or insert one or more instruments into the LUSID instrument master. An instrument will be updated
if it already exists and inserted if it does not.
            
In the request each instrument definition should be keyed by a unique correlation id. This id is ephemeral
and is not stored by LUSID. It serves only as a way to easily identify each instrument in the response.
            
The response will return both the collection of successfully updated or inserted instruments, as well as those that failed.
For the failures a reason will be provided explaining why the instrument could not be updated or inserted.
            
It is important to always check the failed set for any unsuccessful results.
Retrieves a translation script to be used for translating financial entities.

endpoints.summary: Retrieve a translation script by its identifier.

methods.description:
Translates one or more instruments into the given target dialect.
            
In the request each instrument definition should be keyed by a unique correlation id. This id is ephemeral
and is not stored by LUSID. It serves only as a way to easily identify each instrument in the response.
            
Any instrument that is not already in the LUSID dialect should be given as an ExoticInstrument.
            
The response will return both the collection of successfully translated instruments in the target dialect,
as well as those that failed.
For the failures a reason will be provided explaining why the instrument could not be updated or inserted.

endpoints.summary: Translate instruments to a given target dialect.

methods.description:
Retrieve one or more structured result data items from a particular scope.
            
Each item can be identified by its time invariant structured result data identifier. For each ID, LUSID
returns the most recently matched item with respect to the provided (or default) effective datetime. 
            
An optional maximum age range window can be specified to control how far back to look from the specified
effective datetime. LUSID returns the most recent item within this window.
            
In the request, each data item must be keyed by a unique correlation ID. This ID is ephemeral and not stored by LUSID.
It serves only to easily identify each data item in the response.

The response returns three collections. The first contains successfully retrieved data items. The second contains those with a
valid identifier but that could not be found. The third contains those that failed because LUSID could not construct a valid identifier from the request.

For the IDs that failed to resolve or could not be found, a reason is provided.
            
It is important to check the failed sets for any unsuccessful results.

Create or update one or more structured result store address definition data maps in a particular scope. Note these are immutable and cannot be changed once created.
            
In the request, each data map must be keyed by a unique correlation ID. This ID is ephemeral and not stored by LUSID.
It serves only to easily identify each data map object in the response.
            
The response returns both the collection of successfully created or updated data maps, as well as those that failed.
For each failure, a reason is provided.
            
It is important to check the failed set for any unsuccessful results.

Delete one or more structured result data items from a particular scope. Each item is identified by a unique ID which includes
information about its type as well as the exact effective datetime (to the microsecond) at which it entered the system (became valid).
            
In the request, each data item must be keyed by a unique correlation ID. This ID is ephemeral and not stored by LUSID.
It serves only to easily identify each data item in the response.
            
The response returns both the collection of successfully deleted data items, as well as those that failed.
For each failure, a reason is provided.
            
It is important to check the failed set for any unsuccessful results.

Delete the specified Index Convention from a single scope.
The response will return either detail of the deleted item, or an explanation (failure) as to why this did not succeed.
It is important to always check for any unsuccessful response.

Get a Index Convention from a single scope.
The response will return either the conventions that has been stored, or a failure explaining why the request was unsuccessful.
It is important to always check for any unsuccessful requests (failures).

endpoints.summary: Methods for the storage and retrieval of flow conventions.

methods.description: Define a new derived property.

Delete one or more specified quotes from a single scope. A quote is identified by its unique id which includes information about
the type of quote as well as the exact effective datetime (to the microsecond) from which it became valid.
            
In the request each quote must be keyed by a unique correlation id. This id is ephemeral and is not stored by LUSID.
It serves only as a way to easily identify each quote in the response.
            
The response will return both the collection of successfully deleted quotes, as well as those that failed.
For the failures a reason will be provided explaining why the quote could not be deleted.
            
It is important to always check the failed set for any unsuccessful results.

Get one or more items of complex market data from a single scope.
            
Each item can be identified by its time invariant complex market data identifier.
            
For each id LUSID will return the most recent matched item with respect to the provided (or default) effective datetime.
            
An optional maximum age range window can be specified which defines how far back to look back for data from the specified effective datetime.
LUSID will return the most recent item within this window.
            
In the request each complex market data id must be keyed by a unique correlation id. This id is ephemeral and is not stored by LUSID.
It serves only as a way to easily identify each item in the response.
            
The response will return three collections. One, the successfully retrieved complex market data. Two, those that had a
valid identifier but could not be found. Three, those that failed because LUSID could not construct a valid identifier from the request.
            
For the ids that failed to resolve or could not be found a reason will be provided explaining why that is the case.
            
It is important to always check the failed and not found sets for any unsuccessful results.

methods.description:
Get one or more quotes from a single scope.
            
Each quote can be identified by its time invariant quote series id.
            
For each quote series id LUSID will return the most recent quote with respect to the provided (or default) effective datetime. 
            
An optional maximum age range window can be specified which defines how far back to look back for a quote from the specified effective datetime.
LUSID will return the most recent quote within this window.
            
In the request each quote series id must be keyed by a unique correlation id. This id is ephemeral and is not stored by LUSID.
It serves only as a way to easily identify each quote in the response.
            
The response will return three collections. One, the successfully retrieved quotes. Two, those that had a
valid quote series id but could not be found. Three, those that failed because LUSID could not construct a valid quote series id from the request.

For the quotes that failed or could not be found a reason will be provided explaining why the quote could not be retrieved.
            
It is important to always check the failed and not found sets for any unsuccessful results.

description:
Api for creating and managing resource definitions and resource instances.

The Resource Definition endpoints manage resources required for other systems.  These resources can go on to have permissions assigned to them or be added to groups within the AAA Groups Api.

The Resource Instance endpoints manage instances of the definitions previously created.  These instances might have permissions assigned to them or be added to groups via the AAA Groups Api. 

For example, I might define a resource called portfolio using the definitions endpoints.  I could then create three instances of a portfolio called "High Risk Portfolio", "Moderate Risk Portfolio" & "Low Risk Portfolio".

Management of all of the above examples would happen within this API.
title: AAA Resources API

methods.description:
Example Url Calls:
  • Get with specified limit:
    • /api/resources/definitions?limit=10
  • Get without limit:
    • /api/resources/definitions
  • Get with name of scott:
    • /api/resources/definitions?name=scott
  • Get with name beginning with s and limit of 10:
    • /api/resources/definitions?name=s&limit=10
  • Get with modified date since 11:00 UTC on April 30, 2021:
    • /api/resources/definitions?updatedOn=2021-04-30T11:00:00Z
  • Get with offset 20:
    • /api/resources/definitions?offset=20

Implementation Notes:
  • The new resource object in the body of the request will have all fields validated before creating the record.

Implementation Notes:
  • The id of the user to be deleted is checked for existence before executing the delete process.
  • In order for the delete to work, the namespace value in the ResourceDefinition object must match the namespace in the header.

Implementation Notes:
  • A record will only be returned if the namespace in the header matches the namespace associated with the definition.

Implementation Notes:
  • The UpdateResourceDefinition object in the body of the request will have all fields validated before attempting an update.
  • In order for the update to work, the namespace value in the exiting resource object must match the namespace in the header.
  • Likewise the version number in the UpdateResourceDefinition object must match the version number of the record in our data store.

Example Url Calls:
  • Get with specified limit:
    • /api/resources/instances?limit=10
  • Get without limit:
    • /api/resources/instances
  • Get with name of scott:
    • /api/resources/instances?name=scott
  • Get with name beginning with s and limit of 10:
    • /api/resources/instances?name=s&limit=10
  • Get with type of d8302aa1-d813-4422-8abc-6b49b1af2b5c:
    • /api/resources/instances?type=d8302aa1-d813-4422-8abc-6b49b1af2b5c
  • Get with name beginning with s and type of d8302aa1-d813-4422-8abc-6b49b1af2b5c and a limit of 10:
    • /api/resources/instances?name=s&type=d8302aa1-d813-4422-8abc-6b49b1af2b5c&limit=10
  • Get with modified date since 11:00 UTC on April 30, 2021:
    • /api/resources/definitions?updatedOn=2021-04-30T11:00:00Z
  • Get with offset 10:
    • /api/resources/instances?offset=10

Implementation Notes:
  • The NewResourceInstnace object in the body of the request will have all fields validated before creating the record.

Implementation Notes:
  • The id of the Resource Instance to be deleted is checked for existence before executing the delete process.
  • In order for the delete to work, the namespace value in the user object must match the namespace in the header.

Implementation Notes:
  • A record will only be returned if the namespace in the header matches the namespace associated with the resource instance.

Implementation Notes:
  • The UpdateResourceInstance object in the body of the request will have all fields validated before attempting an update.
  • In order for the update to work, the namespace value in the existing resourceintance object must match the namespace in the header.
  • Likewise the version number in the UpdateResourceInstance object must match the version number of the record in our data store.

methods.description:
Returns a paginated list of user's query execution definitions (QEDs).
The list can contain a maximum of 5000 definitions at any given time.
In case API Gateway returns 502 Bad Gateway, you should reduce the number of returned QED fields by using either
the whitelist or blacklist capability.

This endpoint accepts the following query parameters:
* limit: defines the page size (0 > limit >= 5000);
* offset: defines the page offset
* sort: defines the QED field used for sorting
* direction: defines the sorting direction (asc/desc)
* whitelist: comma-separated list of QED fields that will only appear
* blacklist: comma-separated list of QED fields that will not appear

This endpoint enables end-users to generate reports based on their input.
If successful, the endpoint returns an UUID of query execution definition (QED) that was created.
Example requests and data types can be found in the documentation.
Retrieves a selected query execution definition (QED) by its requestId (e.g. returned by POST).

methods.description:
Lists the properties available in a specified view, along with the capabilities they support. Not all documents in the view necessarily support all these properties. A given property is defined the same way whichever view(s) it appears in; if you want the full set, just specify the `SearchAll` view.
Metadata responses are large and changes are infrequent, typically weeks if not months apart. Callers may wish to cache responses and use the `ETag`/`If-None-Match` mechanism to avoid re-downloading and re-parsing the same data again. These header values [MUST](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7232#section-2.3) be double-quoted.

Metadata responses are large and changes are infrequent, typically weeks if not months apart. Status of all completed or failed write requests will be available for up to 14 days and after that will be removed without any further notice. The job id is never reused so any query for status after 14 days will result in "404 Not Found" error.
The 14 days limit is only applicable for completed requests, specifically ones with status COMPLETED or FAILED. Requests in ACCEPTED or STARTED status do not trigger any removal timers.

methods.description:
## General description

For a given parameters returns a saved JSON schema describing the allowable structure for a metadata registration in referred to domain.

The schema is always returned as-is retaining its original packaging. There are two ways to add the schema - as single JSON file and as a packaged ZIP file. If a schema was added as a single JSON file that will be the response format. If it was added as a zipped, multi-file form, then that is exactly what this API will return.

## Side-notes

Disclaimer 1: Zip files are returned as either application/zip or application/octet-stream, in the future only application/zip will remain.

methods.description:
Deletes an existing validation rule by its ruleName.

A delete of the validation rule is always possible in synchronous mode as in principle all rule deletions are relaxations of the validation rules. Metadata validated against n+1 rules will always pass for n rules.
Gets the validation rule definition by its name.

Updates an existing validation rule by its ruleName.

The request is asynchronous, and status can be checked using the information from the API response object.

Full metadata re-validation is required for all updated validation rule, the requirement is that no validation is allowed to invalidate existing metadata. The validatoion can either:
* enforce already existing connection patterns (the metadata is already compliant with the added validation rule)
* enforce the rules for metadata that wasn't added yet
* in case of updates a rule can be relaxed (e.g. more possible target classes added to the statement)

methods.description:
This API allows to get existing referential validation rule added for a specified domain and subdomain and rulename.

If not provided the schema version is set to latest available one.

The "className" parameter can be used to further filter the results to limit them only to the desired class of objects. It is optional and when not provided the validators defined for any class in the subdomain will be returned.
the special chars like '#' in "className" should replaced by '%23'

Creates an entirely new referential validation rule.

The request is asynchronous, and status can be checked using the information from the API response object.

Full metadata re-validation is required for added validation rule, the requirement is that no validation is allowed to invalidate existing metadata. The validation can either:
* enforce already existing connection patterns (the metadata is already compliant with the added validation)
* enforce the rules for metadata that wasn't added yet
see /lifecycle-transitions/{domain}/{subdomain}

methods.description:
**Functionality**

Provides full-text search capability over a set of fields. The specific list of available fields is changing depending on the stored data and is by design irrelevant for this API (which aims to provide a general search capability without specifically targetting any field).

So far there are certain required fields that will be required for all searchable content and that will be used in the general search in all cases. These fileds are so far the `naturalName` and `class`.

The bulk of available fields are dynamically changing (optional) fields. Some examples of these could be `description` and `tags` but the fields themselves can be very specific to the content itself.

Please note that because of special characters being used in the URI - it needs to be encoded according to Percentage-encoding standard.

This API allows to search the metadata only from the "latest" schema version.

**Query Syntax**

All contents of the query expression are by default whitespace-tokenized. If no extra operators are provided it is assumed that all words after tokenization are in OR relation to each other meaning that any of them can be used to match a document and it's the scoring that will sort the documents in a way to present those that match the best first.

The default sort order is determined by the BM25 score of the matched documents. Sorting order can be changed for a different one using one of the parameters.

The input for the query parameter follows the syntax available for query string query available in elasticsearch but with some limitations.
* exact matching: `earnings` will match all documents in `earnings` word in any of the avaiable fields
* multi-word matching: `earnings report` will match all documents that contain `earnings` or `report` words in any of the available fields
* prefix matching: `cat*` that matches a prefix - in this example will match words like `category` and `catalog`
* phrase matching: `"earnings report"` will match both words exactly in that order, both present in one field
* AND-like matching: `+earnings +report` will match only documents that contain both `earnings` and `report` words in any of the fields in any order
* OR-like matching: enabled by default, and doesn not require any operator to work. Can be declared explicitly by using the `|` operator e.g. `earnings | report`.
* negation: `-earnings` will match all documents that do not contain `earnings` word in them.

**Query Examples**

The operators can be combined with each other to form more complex logic. The following example: `+earnings +report +-usa +(monthly | quarterly)` says that we want documents that must contain `earnings` and `report`, must not contain `usa` and must contain either `monthly` or `quarterly`.

**Highlighting**

The search matches can be highlighted to present matched areas of the documents in the search response. The syntax of the `highlight` field is field names separated by commas e.g. `description,naturalName`.

Be warned - there are some cases of complex query logic where highlighting might show matches that are not 100% precise.

Highlighting will be added as an extra section under each `_source` section in the response.

**Pagination**

To paginate the responses use `from` and `size` parameters. `From` is the offset from the beggining of the result list, `size` is the size of the response. There is a limit of paging - the results can't be paged across more than 10000 results, furthermore all updates done to the content are immediately visible for paginated query - it might mean that results in already paged content might change. That behavior is expected as this paginated query type does not run in a context fully isolated from write operations.

**Sorting**

Results by default are sorted by score (as indicated above). To change the sort order provide a comma-separated list of pairs `${field}:${sortOrder},${field2}:${sortOrder2}` e.g. `naturalName:desc,payload.description.raw:asc`.There are two available sort orders: asc and desc, ascending and descending respectively.

There is a special sort field called `_score` - it is the same score as would be used in default ordering of search result. If you want to pre-sort by one field but still keep the nested order as "best matches first" you can set sorting like this: `class:asc,_score:desc`.

Warning: not all fields can be used for sorting, as they need to be prepared for that operation (they must not be tokenized). As a general rule only keyword-type fields can be sorted, and such thing can only be configured at indexing stage.

endpoints.summary: General search over a selection of fields

methods.description:
This API is used to resolve a business id into a natural name path expression. The response uses HATEOAS self link format of the metadata read API but in contrast doesn't provide any object data itself.

**Disclaimer** In "Migrated" environment there is a possibility of this API returning multiple matches for a single business id. It is done whenever a shared identity entry is added by migration tooling. All of the returned links are pointing to objects that share the same business id and the same flat payload, but have distinct natural name paths.

endpoints.summary: Resolve global id to natural name path

methods.description: see /lifecycle-transitions/{domain}/{subdomain}
see /lifecycle-transitions/{domain}/{subdomain}

This API allows the user to check the status of asynchronous dump issued using the metadata snapshot dump API. The dump API is asynchronous and this API is one of two ways of checking the dump status (the other being an SNS notification channel). **Disclaimer** Status of all completed or failed write requests will be available for up to 14 days and after that will be removed without any further notice. The job id is never reused so any query for status after 14 will result in "404 Not Found" error.
The 14 days limit is only applicable for completed requests, specifically ones with status COMPLETED or FAILED. Requests in ACCEPTED or STARTED status do not trigger any removal timers.

endpoints.summary: Get asynchronous dump status by job id

methods.description:
**Delete**

Deletes the **root** of metadata subdomain registration.

This API is asynchronous and all operations will be enqueued and executed according to queue order. This is though an internal behavior so to ensure the order of write processing a user must wait for the API response first before issuing another request. Multiple concurrent write requests (from a single or multiple users) will be ordered internally, but no ordering scheme is guaranteed.

The schema validation for the provided payload is done asynchronously and its status will be visible either by subscribing to SNS notification channel or by checking the request in Write Status API. All write requests must be valid against the subdomain schema and in case of validation failure will be rejected. Notifications and Write Status API responses contain the rejection cause for any accepted but failed write request.

As writes are allowed only for the newest schema version for the regular metadata lifecycle this API doesn't allow to select any other schema than the latest thus the lack of such parameter in this API.

 **Delete Cascade**

 Deletes the **root** of metadata subdomain registration along with all its child objects.

 The delete operation will not succeed when a delete does not leave the metadata in a state that is valid according to the schema document for this domain (e.g. if a schema specifies that child is required, if a schema specifies that a collection of children must have at least 1 child).

Has the same functionality as the regular metadata retrieval API (GET /metadata) but in this case the navigation will start only from the registered metadata tree root. All HATEOAS links to children of the root node will point to the regular metadata retrieval api.

When a specific schema version is provided the API can switch to the read-only storage to retrieve metadata registration for the selected schema version.

By default the API will resolve the schema version to the latest one.

This API is used to save a completely new tree at a the **root** of the domain. It accepts any subtree of metadata registration that is valid according to the subdomain-specific schema.

This API is asynchronous and all operations will be enqueued and executed according to queue order. This is though an internal behavior so to ensure the order of write processing a user must wait for the API response first before issuing another request. Multiple concurrent write requests (from a single or multiple users) will be ordered internally, but no ordering scheme is guaranteed.

The schema validation for the provided payload is done asynchronously and its status will be visible either by subscribing to SNS notification channel or by checking the request in Write Status API. All write requests must be valid against the subdomain schema and in case of validation failure will be rejected. Notifications and Write Status API responses contain the rejection cause for any accepted but failed write request.

As writes are allowed only for the newest schema version for the regular metadata lifecycle this API doesn't allow to select any other schema than the latest thus the lack of such parameter in this API.

For the migration a header parameter can be provided to override this behavior but "Migrated" environment must be used for the operation to succeed; this feature is temporary and will be removed with little/no notice.

For all payloads the **name** is a required element on per-object level unless it's a root element of the subdomain where using the name is forbidden. Name parameter is used to set an individual natural name for all objects in the metadata content. The only exception to this rule is the domain root itself which is automatically resolvable just by providing the domain and subdomain. Its role is to provide an entrypoint for the metadata exploration and it is the base of any registration so it is not needed to name it in any way.

For overwrite request that the payload is an array of objects, the old array will be overwrite by the new array.

This API is used to update the **root** of the subdomain.

This API is asynchronous and all operations will be enqueued and executed according to queue order. This is though an internal behavior so to ensure the order of write processing a user must wait for the API response first before issuing another request. Multiple concurrent write requests (from a single or multiple users) will be ordered internally, but no ordering scheme is guaranteed.

The schema validation for the provided payload is done asynchronously and its status will be visible either by subscribing to SNS notification channel or by checking the request in Write Status API. All write requests must be valid against the subdomain schema and in case of validation failure will be rejected. Notifications and Write Status API responses contain the rejection cause for any accepted but failed write request.

As writes are allowed only for the newest schema version for the regular metadata lifecycle this API doesn't allow to select any other schema than the latest thus the lack of such parameter in this API.

By design the PUT requests are not able to change the natural name of any object. If such a change is requested in the payload the request will be rejected.

**Warning** - This API allows to write on a single-object level. That means that any changes that affect children of the base element in any way are not allowed. Single object is a JSON object with only simple-typed fields or arrays of simple types only (flat properties).

endpoints.summary: Get metadata by natural name path

methods.description:
Search API that is a direct passthrough to Elasticsaerch cluster. Enables quick prototyping of UI search features without provisioning dedicated APIs for each one. The body is a valid Elasticsearch query which can contain queries, aggregations, sort orderings, highlighting definitions, etc. Any valid Elasticsearch is accepted in this API as well, and Elasticsearch is the module that does the validation of incoming requests. This API just relies the rejections from Elasticsearch side as-is.

API allows only read operations (can only issue POST request to the underlying cluster, only to _search endpoint and only for latest version of full search domain).

This API allows to search the metadata only from the "latest" schema version.

**DISCLAIMER** - this API will be removed once feature set stabilizes in UI and backend team catches up with higher priority tasks. It will be replaced by a set of dedicated APIs exposing desired functionality but in a safe manner.

**DISCLAIMER** - the other purpose of this passthrough is to enable UI accessing Elasticsearch cluster from Refinitiv Workspace in a way that doesn't expose the cluster directly.

endpoints.summary: Search API that is a direct passthrough to Elasticsearch cluster

methods.description:
## General description

Saves a new schema for the domain. The schema is validated to be loadable by JSON Schema support library, and needs to pass schema format validations specific to Metadata Store.

Adding a schema automatically triggers the new version to be recognized as latest schema version.

The schema is understood as a definition that is a valid JSON Schema in Draft 7 version of the standard.

## Uploading schema file

To upload schema in a file, content-type:multipart/form-data has to be used. Filename should be suffixed with one of supported file name extension:
* json
* zip

Examples of supported file names:
* cdf-schema.json
* cdf-object-type.zip

## Single-file schemas
The single-file schema, given as a single json file. Using $ref in this format is limited only to the local dependencies defined in the same file, or to define a Reference (which is a system-provided dependency). The size limit of this format is 2MB and schemas above this size will be rejected.

## Multi-file schemas

Schemas transported as ZIP files must contain a single root element called *SchemaRoot.json*. It will be treated as the entrypoint to the entire schema and whole structure will be resolved starting from it.
The size limit for this format is 100MB and schemas above this size will be rejected.

## Suppressing latest version upgrade

An automatic latest version upgrade can be suppressed for metadata migration purposes. A header parameter is used to acheive that goal.

The suppression effect is not permanent, so if a request with suppressed schema version upgrade is followed by another one without the suppression - the version will be changed appropriately by the second request.

This feature is temporary and will be removed with little/no notice.

methods.description:
## General description

Submits a request to transition the metadata writes between the admin statuses.

Transitioning metadata creates a snapshot of the current state of "Created" admin status, and propagates it to "Registered"/"Released".

Lifecycle transition is an asynchronous operation, any client code must either wait for notification or use write status API to check the progress.

Only the latest schema version can be affected by lifecycle transitions. There is no option to select a specific schema version.

  * The only writable state is "Created", all PUT, POST and DELETE requests are affecting only the metadata in this state. It is used for drafting changes.
  * The "Registered" is deemed to be drafted and can be consumed by automation toolings.
  * The "Released" state is deemed to be stable and ready for consumption.

### Transition types
The following subsections contain the only allowable transitions. Any other combination of states will cause an error.

#### From "Created" to "Registered"
Takes the snapshot of the metadata state at "Created" admin status to "Registered" state.

#### From "Registered" to "Released"
Moves the snapshot of the metadata state from "Registered" to "Released" to make it officially available for consumption.

#### From "Released" to "Created"
Clones the snapshot of metadata from the "Released" state and latest schema version of the configured environment to "Created" state of the current environment.
This will be used to the serve the need of metadata cross-environment promotion and retaining the allocated business id.
* In PROD environment, it will clone the metadata from PPE "Released" status with the latest schema version.
* QA environment "Released" metadata is NOT allowed to be promoted to PPE environment.
* In QA environment (for MS developers only), it will clone the metadata from DEV "Released" status with the latest schema version.

## Validations
All lifecycle transitions have validations associated with them that can block the request from succeeding until the found issue is removed. The list of lifecycle-related validations is short today but will be expanded heavily in the future as the product development progresses.

The topic of validations that will happen for the lifecycle transitions is very broad and too complex to be discussed here, please consult with project team to get more insight if necessary.

#### Referential validations
All objects moved to higher admin status must only point at stable targets. That means that while in "Created" admin status it is enough for the target to exist, the transitions enforce that the target is Released first (and thus, deemed stable and ready for consumption).

## Interaction with writes
The write operations (DELETE, PUT, POST /metadata) are serialized with the lifecycle transition operation. Assuming that a single client thread sends the write requests and lifecycle transition, and waits for 202 Accepted response, then all writes happening before the lifecycle transition request will be processed first and then transitioned from "Created" to "Registered", then to "Released" admin status. Any writes that follow the lifecycle transition will remain in "Created" admin status and will be processed after lifecycle transition finishes.

description:
Api for creating and managing permission definitions and permission sets.

The Permission Definition endpoints manage the definition of permissions required for other systems.

These permission definitions can then be assigned to users or groups via permission sets.

The Permission Sets endpoints manage the assignation of the definitions previously created.

methods.description:
Example Url Calls:
  • Get with permission of read and with specified limit of 10:
    • /api/permissions/definitions?permission=read&limit=10
  • Get with entity group:0005941c-119c-40b0-ab8f-ae9cf92c9145 and without limit:
    • /api/permissions/definitions?entity=group:0005941c-119c-40b0-ab8f-ae9cf92c9145
  • Get with permission of read and with entity group:0005941c-119c-40b0-ab8f-ae9cf92c9145:
    • /api/permissions/definitions?permission=read&entity=group:0005941c-119c-40b0-ab8f-ae9cf92c9145
  • Get permission definitions modified since 11:00 UTC on April 30, 2021:
    • /api/permissions/definitions?updatedOn=2021-04-30T11:00:00Z
  • Get with offset 20:
    • /api/permissions/definitions?offset=20

description: The Market Share Reporter Data Service is an API for serving aggregated trading data, as well as reference data, for the purposes of loading into Power BI reports for visualization. Its usage is restricted to machine accounts with the appropriate permissions and it is not currently generally available for end users.
title: Market Share Reporter Data Service

methods.description:
The trading data API provides aggregated trading volume data for all covered instruments (worldwide equities), broken down by several filters.
Different temporal aggregations are available: day, month, quarter.
Data can be retrieved for instruments or indexes.
Returns the HTTP request methods supported. Only GET is supported.

The reference data API is used to load reference data / metadata tables into Power BI. 
The reference data shall always be the most recently available version.
User shall specify the type in the argument. All reference data shall be returned in a single call for each data type.
Returns the HTTP request methods supported. Only GET is supported.
